authors.name: Tibor Grasser
affiliation: Institute for Microelectronics, Technische Universität Wien, Vienna, Austria

p: Tibor Grasser (SM'05) received the Diplomingenieur degree in communications engineering, the Ph.D. degree in technical sciences, and the venia docendi in microelectronics from the Technische Universität Wien, Wien, Austria, in 1995, 1999, and 2002, respectively.

He is currently an Associate Professor with the Institute for Microelectronics, Technische Universität Wien. Since 1997, he has headed the Minimos-NT development group, working on the successor of the highly successful MiniMOS program. He was a visiting Research Engineer with Hitachi Ltd., Tokyo, Japan, and the Alpha Development Group, Compaq Computer Corporation, Shrewsbury, MA. From 2003 to 2010, he was the Director of the Christian Doppler Laboratory for TCAD in Microelectronics. He is the editor of a book on advanced device simulation and organic electronics. He is the coauthor or author of more than 300 papers in scientific books, journals, and conferences proceedings. He has presented invited talks, tutorials, and short courses at various conferences such as the IEEE International Electron Devices Meeting (IEDM), International Reliability Physics Symposium (IRPS), The International Conference on Simulation of Semiconductor Processes and Devices (SISPAD), European Solid-State Device Research Conference (ESSDERC), IEEE International Integrated Reliability Workshop (IIRW), European Symposium on Reliability of Electron Devices, Failure Physics and Analysis (ESREF), Insulating Films on Semiconductors (INFOS), International Sustainable Development Research Society (ISDRS), and the Electrochemical Society (ECS) meetings. His current scientific interests include circuit and device simulation, device modeling, and reliability issues.

Dr. Grasser has been involved in the program committees of conferences such as IEDM, IRPS, SISPAD, IWCE, ESSDERC, IIRW, and ISDRS. He was also a chairman of SISPAD 2007. He was the recipient of the Best Paper Awards at IRPS (2008 and 2010) and ESREF 2008.

authors.name: Ben Kaczer
affiliation: IMEC, Leuven, Belgium

p: Ben Kaczer received the M.S. degree in physical electronics from Charles University, Prague, Czech Republic, in 1992 and the M.S. and Ph.D. degrees in physics from The Ohio State University, Columbus, in 1996 and 1998, respectively.

During his doctoral years, he researched on the ballistic electron emission microscopy of $\hbox{SiO}_{2}$ and SiC films. In 1998, he joined the reliability group of IMEC, Leuven, Belgium, where his activities included the research of the degradation phenomena and the reliability assessment of $\hbox{SiO}_{2}$, SiON, high- $k$, and ferroelectric films; planar and multiple-gate field-effect transistors; circuits; and the characterization of Ge/III–V and metal–insulator–metal devices. He is currently a Senior Reliability Scientist with IMEC. He is the author or coauthor of more than 250 journal and conference papers, presented invited papers, and tutorials at several international conferences.

Dr. Kaczer has served or is serving at various functions at the IEDM, IRPS, SISC, INFOS, and WoDiM conferences. He was the recipient of the OSU Presidential Fellowship and support from Texas Instruments, Inc., three Best and Outstanding Paper Awards from IRPS, and the Best Paper Award from IPFA. He is currently serving on the IEEE Transactions on Electron Devices editorial board.

authors.name: Wolfgang Goes
affiliation: Institute for Microelectronics, Technische Universität Wien, Vienna, Austria

p: Wolfgang Goes was born in Vienna, Austria, in 1979. He received the Dipl.-Ing. degree in technical physics with Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria, in 2005. His diploma thesis addressed grain boundaries in back-contact solar cells. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree with the Institute for Microelectronics, Vienna University of Technology.

In 2007, he was a Visitor with the Department of Physics and Astronomy, Vanderbilt University, Nashville, TN. His current research interests include the first-principles simulations of the chemical processes involved in NBTI and HCI, the modeling of tunneling and charge trapping in dielectrics, and reliability issues in general.

authors.name: Hans Reisinger
affiliation: Infineon, Munich, Germany

p: Hans Reisinger received the Diploma degree in physics and the Ph.D. degree from the Technical University of Munich, Munich, Germany, in 1979 and 1982, respectively.

In 1983, he was with the IBM T. J. Watson Research Center, Yorktown Heights, NY. His topics of research were electronic properties of 2-D space-charge layers on Si and III–V semiconductors. In 1986, he joined the Semiconductor Department, Siemens (now Infineon Technologies). His work was focused on the study of thin dielectrics and interfaces in DRAMs and NVMs, including film fabrication and optical and electrical characterization. He is currently with the Infineon Central Reliability Department, Infineon Technologies, Villach, Austria and works on the threshold instabilities of metal–oxide–semiconductor field-effect transistors with $\hbox{SiO}_{2}$ and HiK dielectrics.

authors.name: Thomas Aichinger
affiliation: Pennsylvania State University, University Park, PA, USA

p: Thomas Aichinger was born in Villach, Austria, in 1983. He received the Mag.rer.nat. degree in physics from the University of Graz, Graz, Austria, in 2007 and the Ph.D. degree from Kompetenzzentrum für Automobil- und Industrieelektronik, Villach, in 2010, through collaboration with Infineon Technologies, Villach, and Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria.

During his diploma thesis, he was integrated with the Quality and Reliability Group, Infineon Technologies, Villach. Since January 2011, he has been a Postdoctoral Researcher with the Semiconductor Spectroscopy Laboratory, Pennsylvania State University, University Park. His research interests include electrically detected magnetic resonance in silicon- and silicon-carbide-based semiconductors.
Dr. Aichinger was a recipient of the 2008 ESREF Best Paper Award.

authors.name: Philipp Hehenberger
affiliation: Institute for Microelectronics, Technische Universität Wien, Vienna, Austria

p: Philipp Hehenberger was born in Vienna, Austria, in 1980. He received the Dipl.-Ing. degree in technical physics from the Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria, in 2006. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree with the Institute for Microelectronics, Vienna University of Technology.
In 2008, he was a Visitor with the School of Microelectronics, Fudan University, Shanghai, China. His current research interests include the device modeling of NBTI.

authors.name: Paul-Jürgen Wagner
affiliation: Institute for Microelectronics, Technische Universität Wien, Vienna, Austria

p: Paul-Jürgen Wagner was born in Vienna, Austria, in 1979. He received the Dipl.-Ing. degree in electrical engineering from Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria, in 2007. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree with the Institute for Microelectronics, Vienna University of Technology.

authors.name: Franz Schanovsky
affiliation: Institute for Microelectronics, Technische Universität Wien, Vienna, Austria

p: Franz Schanovsky was born in Linz, Austria, in 1981. He received the B.Sc. degree in electrical engineering and the M.Sc. degree in microelectronics from Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria, in 2006 and 2008, respectively. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree with the Institute for Microelectronics, Vienna University of Technology.
His current research interests include atomistic modeling in the context of semiconductor device reliability and electronic structure methods.

authors.name: Jacopo Franco
affiliation: IMEC, Leuven, Belgium

p: Jacopo Franco received the B.Sc. and M.Sc. degrees in electronic engineering from the University of Calabria, Cosenza, Italy, in 2005 and 2008, respectively. His M.Sc. thesis was developed with IMEC, Leuven, Belgium, and it is related to the reliability issues in advanced silicon and germanium MOSFETs. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree with the Reliability Group of IMEC, Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Leuven, on the topic of “Interface stability and reliability of Ge and III–V transistors for future CMOS applications.”
He is the author or coauthor of more than 30 publications.
Mr. Franco was the recipient of the IEEE SISC Ed Nicollian Award for the best student paper in 2009.

authors.name: María Toledano Toledano Luque
affiliation: IMEC, Leuven, Belgium

p: María Toledano Luque was born in Madrid, Spain, in 1980. She received the M.Sc. degree in electrical engineering, the M.Sc. degree in physics, and the Ph.D. degree from the Universidad Complutense de Madrid (UCM), Madrid, Spain, in 2003, 2009, and 2008, respectively.

In 2003, she became a member of the Thin Films and Microelectronics Research Group, UCM. In 2007, she joined the Department of Applied Physics (Electronics), UCM, as an Assistant Professor. She is currently a Postdoctoral Researcher at IMEC, Leuven, Belgium, working in the field of advance electrical characterization.

authors.name: Michael Nelhiebel
affiliation: Infineon, Villach, Austria

p: Michael Nelhiebel received the M.Sc. degree in physics from the Vienna University of Technology, Vienna, Austria, and the Ph.D. degree in solid-state physics from Ecole Centrale Paris, Paris, France, working on interferometry in electron energy loss spectrometry.

In 1999, he joined Infineon Technologies, Villach, Austria as a Reliability Engineer of the silicon wafer production. He is currently a Principal Engineer for reliability within the Quality Department, Automotive Business Division, Infineon Technologies, and is responsible with the development phase for technology-related product reliability. He has coordinated the qualification of major automotive technology platforms and participates in research activities of Infineon Technologies on technology reliability.

abstract: One of the most important degradation modes in CMOS technologies, the bias temperature instability (BTI) has been known since the 1960s. Already in early interpretations, charge trapping in the oxide was considered an important aspect of the degradation. In their 1977 paper, Jeppson and Svensson suggested a hydrogen-diffusion controlled mechanism for the creation of interface states. Their reaction-diffusion model subsequently became the dominant explanation of the phenomenon. While Jeppson and Svensson gave a preliminary study of the recovery of the degradation, this issue received only limited attention for many years. In the last decade, however, a large number of detailed recovery studies have been published, showing clearly that the reaction-diffusion mechanism is inconsistent with the data. As a consequence, the research focus shifted back toward charge trapping. Currently available advanced charge-trapping theories based on switching oxide traps are now able to explain the bulk of the experimental data. We give a review of our perspective on some selected developments in this area.

authors.name: Tim Blackwell
affiliation: Department of Computing, Goldsmiths University of London, London, UK

p: Tim Blackwell received the B.Sc. degree in physics from the University of Bristol, Bristol, U.K., the M.Sc. degree in computer science from the University College London, London, U.K., and the D.Phil. degree in theoretical physics from the University of Sussex, Brighton, U.K.

He is currently a Senior Lecturer with the Department of Computing, Goldsmiths University of London, London. He has researched a wide range of subjects, including quantum field theory, condensed matter theory, computer music, digital art, and swarm intelligence. He is well known for the application of swarms to improvised music. His swarm music system has been the subject of numerous articles, radio programmes, and TV documentaries worldwide. He heads the Live Algorithms for Music Research Network. His work in swarm intelligence has included analogies with atomic physics, multiswarms for the solution of dynamic problems, recombination, stochasticity, and distributions based on the movements of foraging animals.

formulaStrippedArticleTitle: A Study of Collapse in Bare Bones Particle Swarm Optimization
displayPublicationTitle: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
publicationTitle: IEEE Transactions on Evolutionary Computation
abstract: The dynamic update rule of particle swarm optimization is formulated as a second-order stochastic difference equation and general relations are derived for search focus, search spread, and swarm stability at stagnation. The relations are applied to three particular particle swarm optimization (PSO) implementations, the standard PSO of Clerc and Kennedy, a PSO with discrete recombination, and the Bare Bones swarm. The simplicity of the Bare Bones swarm facilitates theoretical analysis and a further no-collapse condition is derived. A series of experimental trials confirms that Bare Bones situated at the edge of collapse is comparable to other PSOs, and that performance can be still further improved with the use of an adaptive distribution. It is conjectured that, subject to spread, stability and no-collapse, there is a single encompassing particle swarm paradigm, and that an important aspect of parameter tuning within any particular manifestation is to remove any deleterious behavior that ensues from the dynamics.

p: Roel Maes (S'11) received the electrical engineering degree from the Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (K.U.Leuven), Belgium, in 2007. He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree at the Computer Security and Industrial Cryptography (COSIC) Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department (ESAT), K.U.Leuven.
His research interests include physically unclonable functions (PUFs) and hardware design security.

He is currently working toward the Ph.D. degree at the Computer Security and Industrial Cryptography (COSIC) Laboratory, Electrical Engineering Department (ESAT), K.U.Leuven.
His research interests include trusted computing and hardware design security.

authors.name: Ingrid Verbauwhede
affiliation: COSIC Research Group, Department of Electrical Engineering (ESAT), Katholieke Universiteit Leuven, Heverlee, Belgium

p: Ingrid Verbauwhede (M'92–SM'00) received the electrical engineering degree and the Ph.D. degree from the Katholieke Universiteit Leuven (K.U.Leuven), Belgium, in 1991.

From 1992 to 1994, she was a postdoctoral researcher and visiting lecturer at the University of California, Berkeley. From 1994 to 1998, she worked for TCSI and ATMEL in Berkeley, CA. In 1998, she joined the faculty of University of California, Los Angeles (UCLA). She is currently a professor at the K.U.Leuven and an adjunct professor at UCLA. At K.U.Leuven, she is a codirector of the Computer Security and Industrial Cryptography (COSIC) Laboratory. Her research interests include circuits, processor architectures and design methodologies for real-time embedded systems for security, cryptography, digital signal processing, and wireless communications. This includes the influence of new technologies and new circuit solutions on the design of next-generation systems on chip. She was the program chair of the Ninth International Workshop on Cryptographic Hardware and Embedded Systems (CHES 07), the 19th IEEE International Conference on Application-Specific Systems, Architectures and Processors (ASAP 08), and the ACM/IEEE International Symposium on Low Power Electronics and Design (ISLPED 02). She was also the general chair of ISLPED 2003. She was a member of the executive committee of the 42nd and 43rd Design Automation Conference (DAC) as the design community chair.

abstract: Currently achievable intellectual property (IP) protection solutions for field-programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) are limited to single large "monolithic" configurations. However, the ever growing capabilities of FPGAs and the consequential increasing complexity of their designs ask for a modular development model, where individual IP cores from multiple parties are integrated into a larger system. To enable such a model, the availability of IP protection at the modular level is imperative. In this work, we propose an IP protection mechanism for FPGA designs at the level of individual IP cores, by making use of the self-reconfiguring capabilities of modern FPGAs and deploying a trusted third party to run a metering service, similar to the work of Giineysu et ah and Drimer et at The proposed scheme makes it possible to enforce a pay-per-use licensing scheme which holds considerable advantages, both for IP core providers as well as for system integrators. Moreover, the scheme has a minimal implementation overhead and is the first of its kind to be solely based on primitives that are already available in recent commercially available FPGA devices. This allows for an immediate and feasible deployment, in contrast to earlier proposed solutions.

abstract: The performance analysis of space-time block-coded multiple-input-multiple-output (STBC-MIMO) systems in Rician fading channels for perfect and imperfect channel state information (CSI) is presented in this paper. Accurate expressions of average bit error rate (BER) and symbol error rate (SER) of STBC-MIMO for multiple phase-shift keying (MPSK) and quadrature amplitude modulation (QAM) are derived. Based on asymptotic analysis and Nakagami approximation for Rician fading, closed-form expressions of approximate average BER and SER are obtained for low and high signal-to-noise ratios (SNRs). By combining the error rate expressions of low SNR and SNRs, approximate BER and SER expressions can be obtained for different SNRs. Computer simulation shows that the theoretical analysis is in good agreement with the simulation results, and the approximate expressions derived from the integration of high and low SNR asymptotic analyses are close to the accurate formulas for different SNRs. The asymptotic analysis at high SNR indicates that the coding gain is affected by the Rice factor, transmit and receive antenna numbers, code rate, and modulation, whereas the diversity gain is governed by the transmit and receive antenna numbers. However, the diversity gain will be zero at high SNR in the presence of estimation errors because of the error floor in the error probability curves.
